titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Henri Chopin Papers
titlestmt.author: by Danijela True, Jennifer Meehan, and Molly Wheeler

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday May 4, 2019 at 03:04

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.physdesc: (89 boxes) + 9 record album storage, 31 broadside, 5 art.
did.abstract: The Henri Chopin Papers document the work and life of French avant-garde poet and musician Henri Chopin. The papers consist of personal and professional correspondence, subject files, writings relating to various publications, artwork, writings of others, photographs, audiovisual materials, and posters spanning the years 1948 to 2009.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from John Benjamins Antiquariat b.v. and Philippe Luiggi on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 2011, 2013.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Boxes 37-53 and 72 (sound recordings): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.
Boxes 54-71 and 73-80 (sound and video recordings): Use of originals is restricted. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.
Box 81 and 122 (computer disks): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies of electronic files may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Henri Chopin Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Henri Chopin Papers. General Collection, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: According to the dealer description, "[the archive] was taken directly from [Chopin's] Studio and living quarters in the house of his daughter...in Dereham, UK" and "extensive work [was] done [by the dealer] to sort, organize and describe the thousands of pieces [of the archive], which were left by Henri in total disorder, and on which no work whatsoever had been done before...the archive [was divided] into 4 major subdivisions: 1. correspondence 2. original works of art (both of Henri and by others) 3. manuscripts for books by Henri 4. audio material (both produced by Henri and by others)."
This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and description, in 2012. The collection was largely maintained in the order in which it was received by the library.

Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are based on those provided by the dealer. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles have been supplied by staff during initial processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

bioghist.head: Henri Chopin (1922-2008)
bioghist.p: Henri Chopin, primarily a French avant-garde poet and musician, but also a painter, graphic artist and designer, typographer, independent publisher, and filmmaker. He was born in Paris on June 18, 1922 and died in Dereham, England on January 3, 2008.

Chopin was a French practitioner of concrete and sound poetry and created recordings using tape recorders, various studio technologies, and the sounds of the human voice. Chopin's published works include the books Le Dernier Roman du Monde (1971), Portrait des 9 (1975), The Cosmographical Lobster (1976), Poésie Sonore Internationale (1979), Les Riches Heures de l'Alphabet (1992) and Graphpoemesmachine (2006); the magazines Cinquième Saison and OU (1958-1974); and typewriter poems, also known as dactylopoèmes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Henri Chopin Papers document the work and life of French avant-garde poet and musician Henri Chopin. The papers consist of personal and professional correspondence, subject files, writings relating to various publications, artwork, writings of others, photographs, audiovisual materials, and posters spanning the years 1948 to 2009.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into nine series: I. Correspondence and Subject Files, 1960-2004. II. Cinquième Saison and OU Files 1960-2009. III. Artwork, 1967-2006. IV. Works by Others, 1948-2006.V. Photographs, circa 1960-2000. VI. Writings, 1952-2007. VII. Audiovisual Material, 1957-2007. VIII. Posters, 1967-2006. IX. September 2013 Acquisition, 1963-2007.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The first run of correspondence is arranged alphabetically by correspondent. The second run of correspondence is arranged by the correspondents' country of origin and other subjects. Filed at the end of the series is various correspondence not included with the others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I consists of files of correspondence and other material shedding light on Chopin's development as an artist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series VII includes non-commercial and commercially released audiovisual material containing performances, interviews, studio recordings, and other recordings documenting the work of Henri Chopin and other musicians and poets. The Sound Recordings subseries includes sound recordings by Chopin and others across several formats. Most of the reel-to-reel audiotapes by Chopin were likely used in his performances. The Video Recordings subseries includes VHS, BetacamSP, and DVD recordings of Chopin and his contemporaries. The Other Audiovisual Material subseries contains digital audiotapes and computer disks by Chopin and various sound recording equipment owned by Chopin, including three reel-to-reel tape recorders, two microphones, and an audiotape cutter and scissors.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: Sound Recordings, Video Recordings, and Other Audiovisual Material.

scopecontent.p: Au lendemain de l'invasion de l'Afghanistan par 1'URSS. Voix de l'auteur, à propos des Droits de l'homme, bafoués. Plus le poème "Yalta" écrit à Poznan en 1974 où j'ai vu le dictateur général Jaruselski dans sa hauteur de crétin arrive...Ne prendre que la piste 1, durée 8' 41 secondes, vitesse 19.

did.unittitle: Chopin, Henri. "Les pets du marché commun" (PT 163)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Discours Ministie; avec une chanson de HC, suivie de caquetiges, de maneailles, de boursouflages buccaux, de rots et de gargarismes, de l'usage de curedents, souligné de légers miasmes stomacaux, le tout inspiré par nos assemblées nationales où nos parlementaires mâchent leurs agressivités â défaut de savoir vivre. Ingatestone, Essex, en 19 cm/s. ' or 7 1/2'. Durée environ 8 minutes 10". Et sans effet secondaire à placer en stéréo. Voix de l'auteur, accompagné de sa bouche. Mono.

did.unittitle: Andreyev, Oleg and Edwards, Ken. Where is the Line Between Us?

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Liner notes included with the audiocassette reads: "Teorii" or "Ink abandoned on Paper" was recorded at a private reading late 1983 in East Berlin. Oleg Andreyev born 1937 Kiev/USSR of no permanent address since 1977... "Lexical dub - for Sarah Tisdall". Ken Edwards born Gibraltar 1950 since 1968 in London . Sarah Tisdall, a junior civil servent, was sentenced to 6 months imprisonment for photocopying a memo about cruise missile deployment and disclosing it to the Guardian newspaper.
